case_name: Hukumchand Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 415 of 1965 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 415 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated June 22, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. 34 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated June 22, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in 1. T. R. N. 34 of 1960.

facts.text: Reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Bench A on January 2, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: arise out of a Reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Bench A on January 2, 1959 and decided by the Bombay High Court on September 22, 1962.

facts.text: Bombay High Court decided the reference on September 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: and decided by the Bombay High Court on September 22, 1962. The High Court granted certificates to appeal against its judgment under s. 66-A of the Income Tax Act, 1922

facts.text: High Court granted certificates under s. 66A to both Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central Bombay and the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court granted certificates to appeal against its judgment under s. 66-A of the Income Tax Act, 1922 to both the Commissioner of Income-Tax,  Central  Bombay and the assessee.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965 brought by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965 are brought on behalf of the assessee and Civil Appeals Nos. 414 and 415 of 1965 are brought on behalf of the Commissioner of Income-Tax,  Central  Bombay.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 414 and 415 of 1965 brought by Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965 are brought on behalf of the assessee and Civil Appeals Nos. 414 and 415 of 1965 are brought on behalf of the Commissioner of Income-Tax,  Central  Bombay.

facts.text: Hukumchand Mills Ltd. is a public company incorporated in the previous Indore State.

anchor.surface_text: Hukumchand Mills Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the assessee  is a public companypany incorporated in the previous Indore State.

facts.text: The assessee owns a textile mill in Indore State.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee owns a textile mill there.

facts.text: Up to assessment year 1949-50, assessee assessed in British India as non-resident except 1948-49 as resident.

anchor.surface_text: Up to the assessment year 1949-50 it was being assessed in British India as a number-resident  except in 1948-49 when it was assessed as a resident , on such income as fell within s. 4  1  a  or 4  1  c  read with s. 42 of the Income Tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Assessee assessed on income falling within s.4(1)(a) or 4(1)(c) read with s.42 of the Act as non-resident.

anchor.surface_text: on such income as fell within s. 4  1  a  or 4  1  c  read with s. 42 of the Income Tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Indore became Part B State after Constitution, Act brought into force from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After the Constitution came into force, Indore became a Part B State and the Act was brought into force in such States with effect from April 1, 1950.

facts.text: Assessee became liable to be assessed as resident from assessment year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee therefore became liable to be assessed as a resident from the assessment year 1950-51.

facts.text: Assessee assessed as resident in years 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was accordingly assessed as a resident in the years 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952-53,

facts.text: Question arose on proper written down value of buildings, machinery for depreciation under s.10(2)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: One of the questions which arose for determination in the assessments for these years was the proper written down value of the buildings, machinery etc. of the assessee for calculating the depreciation allowance under s. 10 2  vi  of the Act.

facts.text: Assessee contended original cost should be taken for WDV per s.10(5)(b) as no depreciation allowed under Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee relied upon s. 10 5  b  and companytended that the original companyt of the machinery, buildings etc. should be taken for this purpose. That sub-clause provided that in the case of assets acquired before the previous year the written down value was the actual companyt less all depreciation actually allowed to the assessee under the Act or any Act repealed thereby.

facts.text: Department contended depreciation allowed for total income as non-resident must be taken into account for WDV per s.10(5)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Department, on the companytrary, was that as it was necessary to determine the total income of the assessee to arrive at the taxable proportionate income of the assessee under the Act as a number- resident and as depreciation had been allowed to arrive at such total income, the same must be taken into account to arrive at the written down value as it had been actually allowed within the meaning of s. 10 5   b .

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contention.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the companytention of the assessee

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated October 8, 1958 held only depreciation entering taxable income computation is actually allowed.

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal, by its order dated October 8, 1958 held that only that part of the depreciation which entered into the companyputation of the taxable income of the assessee under the Act can be treated as depreciation actually allowed and number the total depreciation which went into the companyputation of the total income.

facts.text: Department urged before Tribunal provisions of paragraph 2 of Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: it was urged before the Tribunal by the Department that al- though the Income Tax Officer had number companysidered the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Taxation Laws Order ,

facts.text: Tribunal permitted Department's contention on Taxation Laws Order and remanded to ITO.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this submission made by the parties the Tribunal remanded the matter back to the Income Tax Officer for ascertaining whether any depreciation was allowed under the Industrial Tax Rules and for companysidering the question whether the said rules related to income-tax or super-tax or any law relating to tax on profits of business and if he decided these questions in favour of the Department he should take into companysideration such depreciation actually allowed under the said rules for the purposes of companyputing the written down value.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions under s.66(1) to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 66 1 ,of the Act the Tribunal referred the following questions of law for the determination of the High Court

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated June 22, 1962 answered first question in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated June 22, 1962 the High Court agreed with the view taken by the Tribunal on the first question and answered it in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: High Court held paragraph 2 of Taxation Laws Order valid but applicable only if ITO decides questions in favour of Department.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second question, the High Court held as follows- We do number find anything in the Tribunals order which indicates that any companytention was raised before the Tribunal that paragraph 2 had numberapplication to the case. ... In these circumstances, our answer to question No. 2 as framed is that Paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950, is a valid provision of law, but it will have application to the present case only if the questions which the Tribunal has asked the Income-tax officer to determine, are determined by the Income-tax Officer in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we reject the argument of Mr. Bobde on behalf of the assessee and dismiss these appeals.
under s. 66-A of the Income Tax Act, 1922 to both the Commissioner of Income-Tax,  Central  Bombay and the assessee.

issues.text: Whether the words all depreciation actually allowed used in section 10(5)(b) of the Indian Income-tax Act refer only to the depreciation allowed for the purpose of determining the amount liable to Indian income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: lm15 Whether the words all depreciation actually allowed used in section 10 5  b , of the Indian Income-tax Act refer only to the depreciation allowed for the purpose of determining the amount liable to Indian income-tax.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, apply and were correctly applied to the facts of the case.

Rule 12 allows appellant to urge new grounds with leave of Tribunal; Tribunal not confined to memo grounds

Rule 28 empowers Tribunal to remand case with directions if opinion so requires

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second question, the High Court held as follows- We do not find anything in the Tribunals order which indicates that any contention was raised before the Tribunal that paragraph 2 had no application to the case. ... our answer to question No. 2 as framed is that Paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950, is a valid provision of law,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cordingly of the opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to entertain the argument of the Department in this case and to ,direct the Income Tax Off

holdings.text: There is no justification for the argument that the Tribunal was not competent to go into the question of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Order and that the respondent should not have been allowed to raise the contention for the first time before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no justification for this argument. In the first place, no objection was raised before the Tribunal or before the High Court that the Department should not have been allowed to raise the question for the first time with regard to the application of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection raised before Tribunal or High Court; question implicit in referred question.

holdings.text: The Tribunal had jurisdiction to permit the question of applicability of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Order to be raised for the first time in appeal under section 33(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Even upon that assumption we are of opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to permit the question to be raised for the first time in appeal. The powers of the Tribunal in dealing with appeals are expressed in s. 33 4  of the Act in the widest possible terms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 33(4) expresses powers in widest terms, allowing any orders as thinks fit after hearing parties.

holdings.text: Section 33(4) of the Act confers on the Appellate Tribunal all powers conferred on the Appellate Assistant Commissioner under section 31, including power to direct further enquiry and remand.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'pass such orders as it thinks fit' include powers under s.31; restricts only to subject-matter of appeal.

holdings.text: Rule 12 of the Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1946 allows the Tribunal to hear new grounds with leave and is not confined to grounds in memorandum of appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit provision in Rule 12 for new grounds and Tribunal's discretion in deciding appeal.

holdings.text: Rule 27 allows respondent to support order on any grounds decided against it even without filing appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Rule 27 to respondent (Department) supporting order on new ground.

holdings.text: Rule 28 empowers the Tribunal to remand the case with directions if of opinion that it should be remanded.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 28 is to the, following effect Where the Tribunal is of opinion that the case should be remanded, it may remand it to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or the Income-tax Officer, with such directions as the Tribunal may think fit.

holdings.text: Even assuming Rules 12 and 28 not strictly applicable, Tribunal has sufficient power under s.33(4) to entertain the argument and remand.
Rules 12 and 28 are merely procedural and do not circumscribe or control the power under s.33(4).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules procedural, s.33(4) plenary power not limited by rules.

holdings.text: The Tribunal had jurisdiction to entertain the Department's argument and direct ITO to determine depreciation under Industrial Tax Rules for WDV computation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining s.33(4) and rules, within subject-matter of appeal (WDV under s.10(2)(vi)).

holdings.text: Assessee's appeals (Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965) dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we reject the argument of Mr. Bobde on behalf of the assessee and dismiss these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no justification for this argument. In the first place, no objection was raised before the Tribunal or before the High Court that the Department should not have been allowed to raise the question for the first time with regard to the application of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Order.
For these reasons we reject the argument of Mr. Bobde on behalf of the assessee and dismiss these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Even upon that assumption we are of opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to permit the question to be raised for the first time in appeal. The powers of the Tribunal in dealing with appeals are expressed in s. 33 4  of the Act in the widest possible terms.
For these reasons we reject the argument of Mr. Bobde on behalf of the assessee and dismiss these appeals.
